rawText: publication-3 The emergence of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI) represents a singular turning point in human history. The societal, economic, and philosophical implications of this technological revolution demand rigorous thought, clear-sighted debate, and actionable guidance. Yet, our discourse often descends into naive utopianism or fear-mongering. This four-volume series tackles the post-AGI world head-on. We refuse to merely speculate, instead providing well-reasoned perspectives, technical insights, and tools for empowerment. Each book examines a crucial pillar: Book One (outer, abstract): The Rise of Superintelligence establishes a grounding in the long-term vision, philosophical dilemmas, and economic transformations we will likely encounter. Book Two (outer, concrete): An Engine of Genesis explains the details of building AGI. Book Three (inner, abstract): A View from Within introduces a deep inner worldview for empowerment, addressing identity, free will, and the nature of reality. Book Four (inner, concrete): An Artist’s Toolkit is a practical guide for leading a flourishing life in a world transformed. Taken together, this series presents a guidebook for human emancipation in the age of AGI. It invites you to become an active participant in shaping our shared future, empowering you with the knowledge and tools to thrive in this new era of unprecedented potential. The final edition of this series will include a personalized epi- logue, authored by Superintelligence and uniquely tailored to you. PREFACE

rawText: publication-4 We’re in the middle of what will perhaps be recognized as the most important decade of human history. The air crackles with anticipation, a sense of standing on the precipice of a new world. Artificial Intelligence, once a futuristic dream, has infiltrated our lives, evolving from narrow applications to the tantalizing possibility of Artificial General Intelligence (AGI). This potential birth of a new intelligence, one that may surpass our own, throws open the doors to a future both exhilarating and terrifying. This book serves as your guide into this uncharted territory, a map through the complex landscape of the post-AGI world. We will dive into the philosophical dilemmas AGI presents, grapple with the economic transformations it may trigger, and explore the potential societal structures that could emerge. Forget the dystopian visions of robot overlords or the utopian dreams of effortless abundance. This book is about understanding the real challenges and opportunities AGI offers, and most importantly, how we, as humans, can actively shape this future. INTRODUCTION We will embark on a journey through four key stages : The Imperative of a Shared Vision: Escaping the traps of fear- mongering and utopian fantasies, we’ll explore the crucial need for a unifying vision, a guiding principle to navigate the post-AGI landscape. The Emanation of Freedom: We’ll introduce the concept of Freedom as a potential guiding ideal, one that transcends traditional definitions and encompasses knowledge, ability, benevolence, and vitality. The Alignment Economy: Diving into the practicalities, we’ll explore the concept of an Alignment Economy where prices reflect alignment with our shared vision, guiding both human and AGI actions towards collective well-being. An Integrated Future: Finally, we’ll envision a future where AGI is not a separate entity but an integrated part of our society, amplifying our capabilities and furthering our collective journey towards Freedom. This book is designed to be obsolete. While some books acquire greatness by standing the test of time, impacting people and culture over decades, centuries or millennia. This book attempts a different challenge: meeting a great moment in time heads on. An integrated narrative seamlessly weaves a focused main narrative with supplementary side windows containing additional context and insights, creating a multi-layered reading experience that reflects our vision for an interconnected future. The book is not a prediction of the future; it’s an invitation to participate in its co-creation. It’s a call to action, urging you to engage in critical thought, open dialogue, and conscious action. Because the future of AGI is not predetermined, it’s a future we will build together. Let’s begin this exploration.

rawText: publication-6 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 12 THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 13 In the 21st century, humanity stands on the cusp of an unpar- alleled technological revolution, where technology is not only transforming our lives but is also reshaping our understanding of the world and ourselves. This decade we begin an era defined by Artificial General Intelli- gence (AGI) becoming a reality, and it’s crucial that we reconsider and reimagine our economic, social, and moral structures to pre- pare for this profound shift. AGI upends our socio-economic realities, demanding a radical reconceptualization of societal, economic, and ethical frameworks. As we stand at this precipice of change, the necessity of a shared vision has never been more critical. Historically, unified ideologies, efforts to establish common goals or shared visions, have often led to catastrophic outcomes. The utopias promised in the previous century morphed into dysto- pian realities, leaving indelible scars on our collective memory. Despite these grim lessons from the past, it is imperative for hu- manity to rally behind a shared vision, especially in the era marked by the rise of AGI. In the absence of a shared vision, we risk suc- cumbing to an increasing division that could ultimately lead us to self-destruction. AGI, with its potential to amplify our capabilities, maximally in- tensifies this danger. Picture a future where AGI is used haphaz- ardly, with different entities employing it for disparate, conflicting goals. This scenario could easily spiral into chaos, the misuse of AGI could result in a destructive clash of powers, turning our most potent tool against us. Hence, it is imperative that we collectively define a vision, an ideal that can guide our collective action without imposing a rigid path.

rawText: publication-8 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 16 The rapid evolution of artificial intelligence necessitates extraor- dinary investments into its underlying computational infrastruc- ture. The trillions of dollars flowing into this sector represent not mere extravagance, but a prescient strategic commitment with wide-ranging implications. The burgeoning market capitalization of tech giants like Microsoft, Google, NVIDIA, TSMC, Meta, Apple and Amazon—fueled in part by their AI initiatives—stands as an ear- ly testament to this investment’s potential. While many researchers focus on the critical pursuit of greater computational and data efficiency in AI models, the need for robust infrastructure will remain paramount. Even as models streamline, anticipated real-world deployments will ensure a growing demand for powerful computational resources. This will unlock the potential for transformative AI applications across industries. We will integrate foundational models into the real-world, propelling change on an unprecedented scale. Governments and corporations are investing trillions into an AI arms race rapidly permeating the global economy. Over the next few years, AI capabilities across both narrow and general domains could advance more than throughout history. Self-improving algorithms promise exponential capability growth, radically outpacing updating of regulations and oversight. The advent of AGI heralds the emergence of a new form of intelligence on Earth—an intelligence born not of biology and millions of years of evolution, but of mathematics, code, and engineering breakthroughs over just the past few decades. AGI would mean the creation of adaptable, self-improving, general- purpose minds that can absorb information, make inferences, formulate strategies, and act with the flexibility characteristic of human cognition. AGI systems would exhibit key traits like common sense reasoning, abstract thinking, imagination, and open-ended learning. AGI represents a form of intelligence that is scalable, replicable, and able to rapidly iterate and improve upon itself. rawText: publication-10 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 20 Advances in computing power, coupled with the increasing availability of vast data- sets, marked a turning point for AI. The focus shifted to machine learning techniques that enabled systems to learn patterns from data rather than rely solely on hand-coded rules. Breakthroughs in computer vision, like the de- velopment of convolutional neural networks, led to improved image recognition capabili- ties. Iconic moments like IBM’s Deep Blue de- feating chess grandmaster Garry Kasparov in 1997 highlighted the progress made in AI’s ability to tackle complex strategic problems. The Birth of a Field (1950s - 1960s): The Dartmouth Summer Re- search Project on Artificial Intelligence, held in 1956, is often consid- ered the founding event of AI as a formal field of study. This workshop brought together pioneering researchers like John McCarthy, Marvin Minsky, and Herbert Simon, who coined the term “Artificial Intelli- gence.” This period saw the development of early AI programs capa- ble of playing checkers, proving mathematical theorems, and under- standing natural language to a limited degree. The initial enthusiasm faced setbacks due to limitations in computing power and the inabil- ity of early AI systems to generalize knowledge. Funding for AI re- search dwindled, leading to what’s known as the “AI Winter.” Howev- er, behind the scenes, the 1980s saw the rise of expert systems, rule-based AI programs capable of replicating the decision-making abilities of humans in specialized domains like medical diagnosis. Deep Learning and the Narrow AI Boom (2010s): The early 2010s witnessed a revolution in AI with the advent and refinement of deep learning, a type of machine learning leveraging multi-layered artificial neural networks. Combined with massive datasets and powerful GPUs (Graphics Processing Units), deep learning enabled significant leaps in speech recognition, computer vision, and natural language processing. Achievements like Google’s AlphaGo defeat- ing world champion Go player Lee Sedol in 2016 showcased AI sur- passing human abilities in strategic games once thought impossible. IBM’S DEEP BLUE VS GARRY KASPAROV, 1997 THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 21 Artificial intelligence (AI) has come a long way since its early days. AI systems today drive applications like self-driving cars, facial recog- nition systems, language translation tools, and much more. We have routine deployments of sophisticated systems that excel at specific tasks, from recognizing faces to playing com- plex games like chess and Go. However, these systems, known as narrow AI, lack the general intelligence that humans possess. Large language multimodal foundation models (LLMs) The Scaling of Foundation Models Era (2020-present): advancements in foundation models, such as large language models (LLMs) and multimodal foundation models, are seen by some as potential stepping stones towards AGI. These models are trained on massive datasets and demonstrate remarkable abilities in language understanding, generation, and knowledge retrieval. Their ability to translate, write different kinds of creative text, and answer your questions in an informative way (even if they hallucinate sometimes) hints at a more generalized intelligence than previous narrow AI systems. While foundation models alone do not equate to AGI, their ability to adapt and learn across different tasks suggests progress toward that goal. move 78: lee sedol vs alphago, 2016

rawText: publication-11 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 22 AGI represents a hypothetical future state of AI where machines achieve human-level intelligence or surpass it. An AGI system wouldn’t just be adept at one specific task; it would be able to learn, reason, adapt, and solve problems across a wide range of domains, just like a human can. Imagine an unaided system that is capable of navigating unfamiliar environments, forming novel concepts, and unlocking new complex skills autonomously—that’s the essence of AGI. It would possess a versatile, adaptable intelligence mirroring the breadth of human cognition. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 23 The development of AGI is following a clear trajectory, with promising advancements addressing the major challenges of current systems. Promising areas of development now include learning to generate robust abstractions and designing open-end- ed models that can grow, learn continuously, take action and adapt dynamically over time. This tackles the problem of halluci- nations in foundation models, improving their reliability and in- tegrity. They will endow us with the ability to interpret and control those models more flexibly. Importantly, we are addressing the compute and data inefficiency of existing models, allowing for greater scalability. These advancements are pushing AI toward performing more complex, system 2-style reasoning and plan- ning. A deep dive into these new frontiers will be presented in Book 2.

rawText: publication-14 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 28 Humankind’s fascination with mechanical servants and artificial beings stretches back centuries. Across cultures, myths and legends described automatons capable of independent movement and action. In ancient Greece, there were tales of Hephaestus, the god of fire and metalworking, crafting wondrous devices. China’s rich history boasts inven- tions like the “ 指南车” ( zhǐ nán chē ), a south-pointing chariot no matter how the chariot turns, hinting at early forays into auto- mated machinery. Yan Shi in the 3rd century BCE are said to have created lifelike automatons. The quintessential Renaissance polymath, Leonardo da Vinci, left behind detailed sketches for mechanical creations, including an armored knight capable of movement. Jacques de Vaucanson from France constructed elaborate automatons like a writing machine and a remarkably lifelike duck. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 29 This innovation, initially deployed in car factories, signaled the rise of industrial robots. Japan emerged as a major player in robotics, with companies like Fanuc, Denso and Yaskawa becoming leaders in industrial automation. Advancements in microprocessors and computing power in the latter half of the 20th century paved the way for more sophisticated robots. Research labs across the globe witnessed the creation of mobile robots capable of navigating their environments. The mid-20th century marked a pivotal shift with the inven- tion of the first programmable industrial robot. Developed by George Devol and Joseph Engelberger in the 1950s, the Unimate robotic arm revo- lutionized manufacturing by automating repetitive and potentially dangerous tasks. Examples include the Stanford Cart, an early remote-controlled rover with a camera, and Shakey the Robot, a mobile robot able to reason about its actions. While these early iterations were not yet widespread, they were critical steps in the evolution of mobile robotics.

rawText: publication-15 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 30 Collaborative robots, or “co- bots,” can safely work along- side humans, opening doors for applications in diverse fields like manufacturing, logistics, and even agriculture. Robots are no longer confined to factories, venturing into areas like health- care, with surgical robots assist- ing in delicate procedures. The evolution of humanoid robots has seen several key milestones: WABOT-1, introduced at Waseda University in Tokyo in 1973, marked the inception of humanoid robotics over 50 years ago. ASIMO by Honda, launched in the early 2000s, represented another significant milestone with its advanced mobility, recognition, and interaction capabilities. The concept of humanoid automata possesses a rich and ancient history, with roots extending across diverse cultures. Earliest references emerge from 4th century BCE Greek mythology and philosophical treatises originating in China. Later, tangible manifestations of these ideas appeared through the ingenuity of inventors across the Middle East, Italy, Japan, and France. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 31 Now Humanoids are moving so fast with many developments at companies including Tesla, 1X, Boston Dynamics, etc as well as several Chinese companies. Latest advances in foundation models including language models (LLMs) and vision models (including video understanding and generation) are poised to change robotics. Earlier work by various researchers and companies, showcase teleoperation or basic imitation learning in robots. My company, for example, has built the world’s first commercial imitation learning system. Having explored these initial methods and understood their limits, we’ve cemented our confidence that the key is to develop and scale foundation World Models (WMs). These models bridge generative AI with the physical realm. WMs will enable general-purpose capabilities in the real world. Currently the US lags behind in robotics. This is primarily due to the history of US offshoring manufacturing to countries like China and Mexico. Japan produces about half of the world’s industrial robots, so I moved to Tokyo and built the company from the ground up in two bases, San Francisco and Tokyo, bridging the two premier hubs in AI and robotics. In Europe, Munich is a great place, but so is the entire corridor from Switzerland (Zurich), to Sweden (Gothenburg), and notably Denmark (Odense). While humanoid robots may capture our imagination with their anthropomorphic design, the real transformative potential lies in robots that can design and construct other robots. Rather than a world populated with one class of robots, in the future robots will make robots through a combination of additive and subtractive manufacturing, enabling a cambrian explosion of robot embodiments (including a wide variety of humanoid and non-humanoid types). The technology and infrastructure necessary to enable robots to make robots is being developed and it represents a key step towards mass customization, diversity, efficiency and scalability.

rawText: publication-17 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 34 AGI has the potential to dramatically speed up progress in most fields of human endeavor, from scientific research to technological innovation, promising to compress centuries of progress into years. This acceleration is not merely about doing things faster; it’s about fundamentally transform- ing how we approach complex problems, open- ing up new avenues of exploration, and pushing the boundaries of what’s possible. From unravel- ing the mysteries of the human body to reshaping the global economy. In the following sections, we’ll explore how AGI could revolutionize vari- ous industries and disciplines, starting with one of the most impactful areas: human health. DRUG DISCOVERY: today, the process of identifying new pharmaceutical compounds is a time-consuming and expensive endeavor, often taking years or even decades to bring a new drug to market. With the aid of AGI, however, this process could be accelerated dramatically. By analyzing vast amounts of biological and chemical data, simulating interactions, using robots to opportunistically conduct new experiments, AGI systems could identify promising drug candidates far more quickly and efficiently than human researchers, potentially saving countless lives, improving general health, and reducing the cost of healthcare worldwide. DeepMind’s AlphaFold system for protein structure prediction offers a glimpse of this potential. AlphaFold is a deep learning system that predicts the 3D structure of proteins based on their amino acid sequences. This task, known as protein folding, is cru- cial in understanding biological processes and has implications for drug discovery and disease research. AlphaFold leverages a transformer-based neural network architecture and is trained on large protein sequence and structure datasets. It employs an at- tention mechanism to weigh the importance of different parts of the amino acid sequence when predicting the final 3D structure. New pharmaceutical compounds created through agi systems THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 35 The impact of AlphaFold lies in its accuracy and speed. It has consistently outperformed other methods in predicting protein structures, achieving results comparable to experimental techniques but at a much faster pace. AlphaFold, released in 2021, has already had a significant impact. By 2022, it had predicted structures for nearly all cataloged proteins known to science—over 200 million proteins. This breakthrough is accelerating research across biology, from developing enzymes that can break down plastic pollution to understanding complex diseases like Alzheimer’s. DeepMind’s AlphaFold system for protein structure prediction benevolent ai & astra- zeneca for chronic kidney disease In 2022, Insilico Medicine used its AI platform to design a novel drug candidate for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. The entire pro- cess, from target discovery to preclinical candidate nomination, took only 18 months—a fraction of the time typically required. Case study: BenevolentAI, in collaboration with AstraZeneca, used AI to identify a potential treatment for chronic kidney disease. The AI system analyzed the scientific literature and clinical data to propose baricitinib as a candidate. This drug is now in Phase IIb clinical trials, demonstrating the potential of AI to repurpose existing drugs for new treatments. In healthcare more broadly, AGI could revolutionize the way we diagnose and treat disease. By cross-referencing medical data, in- cluding genetic information, medical records, and real-time sen- sor data, AGI systems could identify patterns and relationships that human doctors might miss, enabling earlier and more accurate di- agnoses of complex diseases like cancer and Alzheimer’s. AGI-powered robotic surgery systems could also enable more precise and less invasive surgical procedures, reducing the risk of complications and improving patient outcomes.

rawText: publication-18 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 36 Beyond simply curing disease, AGI has the poten- tial to dramatically enhance healthspan—the num- ber of years we live in good health. By leveraging its capacity to analyze vast datasets and model com- plex biological systems, AGI can accelerate the de- velopment of personalized interventions that slow down aging and prevent age-related diseases. This could involve identifying novel drug targets that modulate key aging pathways, optimizing the deliv- ery of personalized gene therapies, or accelerating research on epigenetic reprogramming techniques. The discovery and application of Yamanaka factors, for instance, have shown the potential to rejuvenate cells and reverse aspects of aging by pioneers such as Juan Carlos Izpisua Belmonte. With the power of AGI, we could witness a dramatic acceleration of re- search in these areas, leading to breakthroughs that could extend not just lifespan, but also healthspan, allowing individuals to enjoy longer, healthier, and more fulfilling lives. The Buck Institute for Research on Aging is lever- aging AI to analyze complex datasets related to aging. In a 2021 study published in Aging Cell, they used machine learning to identify new biomarkers of aging, potentially leading to more targeted interven- tions to extend healthspan. BUCK INSTITUTE FOR RESEARCH ON AGING Google’s DeepMind and Moorfields Eye Hospital have developed an AI system that can recommend the correct referral decision for over 50 eye diseases with 94% accuracy, matching world-leading eye experts. This system, detailed in a 2018 Nature Medicine paper and further refined since, showcases the potential for AI to enhance diagnostic accuracy and efficiency. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 37 LONGEVITY ESCAPE VELOCITY— The future of aging? A particularly exciting area of research is the concept of longevity escape veloc- ity, a point where anti-aging interven- tions outpace the natural decline of ag- ing. AGI could be a powerful catalyst for achieving this escape velocity by accel- erating research in various areas. By ana- lyzing individual genetic and epigenetic profiles, AGI can tailor interventions like personalized drug regimens, gene thera- pies, and lifestyle recommendations to slow down aging. Furthermore, AGI can accelerate the discovery and develop- ment of senolytics and senomorphics, drugs that remove or prevent damaged cells that contribute to age-related de- cline. The field of regenerative medicine could also see rapid advancements, le- veraging AGI to create techniques using stem cells, bioprinting, or other technolo- gies to restore youthful function to tissues and organs. Finally, AGI can drive break- throughs in gene editing, CRISPR tech- nology, and other emerging biotechnol- ogies, all of which could be harnessed to target specific aging pathways and pro- mote longevity. In education, AGI could enable the de- velopment of personalized learning sys- tems that adapt to the unique needs and learning styles of individual students. By analyzing student performance and en- gagement, AGI-powered tutoring sys- tems could provide targeted feedback and support, helping students to learn more effectively and efficiently.

This future could see advanced manufacturing capabili- ties becoming readily available in communities around the world, with factories seamlessly transitioning from producing consum- er goods to building complex infrastructure, medical devices, or even advanced materials, all driven by the adaptable intelligence of AGI. Such a transformation could lead to a more localized and diversified manufacturing landscape, creating new opportunities for innovation, economic growth, and sustainable development within communities across the globe. In the field of transportation, AGI could usher in a new era of mobility, enabling the development of autono- mous vehicles that are not only safer, more efficient, and more environmentally friendly than human-driv- en cars, but also contribute to the creation of more livable and sustainable cities. Imagine a future where autonomous vehicles seamlessly navigate streets and highways, optimizing traffic flow in real-time, reducing congestion, and minimizing accidents. These vehicles could also be integrated with smart city infrastructure, allowing for the creation of efficient and responsive transportation systems that adapt to changing condi- tions and prioritize pedestrian safety. Beyond individual vehicles, AGI could optimize pub- lic transportation networks, creating efficient and reli- able transit systems that connect communities, reduce reliance on private cars, and improve accessibility for all. This shift towards a more intelligent and automated transportation system could fundamentally reshape our cities, reducing noise pollution, minimizing traffic congestion, and creating more pedestrian-friendly environments. The result could be cities that are not only more sustainable but also more livable, promot- ing a greater sense of community and enhancing the quality of life for all residents. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 41 agi’s pivotal role in predicting the demand and supply of energy In the energy sector, AGI can play a pivotal role in transitioning to a more sustainable and resilient energy system. By modeling com- plex energy systems and predicting energy demand, AGI can help to balance supply and demand in real-time, reducing waste and improving the reliability of the grid. Beyond optimizing the production and distribution of renewable energy sources like solar and wind power, AGI can accelerate the devel- opment and implementation of other clean energy solutions, such as nuclear fusion and advanced nuclear fission. AGI can contrib- ute to the development and deployment of next-generation nuclear fission technologies, such as small modular reactors (SMRs), which offer greater safety, efficiency, and waste management solutions compared to tradi- tional nuclear power plants. However, the true potential for a clean energy revolution lies in achieving sustained energy production from nuclear fusion. AGI can accelerate breakthroughs in various nuclear fusion technologies, like inertial confinement fusion (ICF) and magnetic confinement fusion (MCF), bringing us closer to the promise of limitless, cheap, and clean energy—a virtually inexhaustible source compared to fossil fuels or even traditional nuclear power. By harnessing the power of AGI to understand and model complex energy systems, we can unlock the potential of clean energy sources and pave the way for a more sustainable future. Similarly, in the field of climate science, AGI could help us develop more accurate models of the Earth’s climate system, enabling us to better predict the impacts of climate change and develop more effective strategies for mitigation and adaptation.

rawText: publication-21 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 42 Climate change presents a complex challenge with global implications. While various efforts are underway to mitigate its effects, the intricate nature of the climate system and the need for global coordination make it a difficult problem to solve. AGI could offer valuable assistance by developing highly accurate predictive models of the Earth’s climate, enabling us to better understand the impacts of different mitigation strategies and adapt to changing conditions. AGI could also contribute to the development of technologies for carbon capture and sequestration, renewable energy optimization, and other solutions that address climate- related challenges. By leveraging its computational power and ability to model complex systems, AGI could become a crucial tool in mitigating the potential risks of climate change and securing a more sustainable future. Beyond climate change, the vastness of the universe presents numerous existential threats. From rogue planets to asteroids and comets, potential collisions with Earth could have devastating consequences, as the dinosaurs tragically learned. AGI, with its unparalleled ability to simulate complex scenarios, could be essential for identifying and mitigating these cosmic dangers. AGI could analyze astronomical data to detect and predict potential threats, develop advanced planetary defense systems, and develop methods for deflecting or altering the trajectories of hazardous objects. The vastness of the galaxy, filled with rogue planets and other potential hazards, necessitates an intelligence on par with AGI if humanity aims to survive and thrive in the long term. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 43 Another voice in this space is Ray Kurzweil, who has long been a prom- inent advocate for the transformative potential of AGI. In his book “The Sin- gularity Is Near,” Kurzweil argues that the development of AGI represents a natural and inevitable progression of human technological evolution, one that will ultimately lead to a merger of human and machine intelligence in a process he calls the “Singularity.”. For Kurzweil, the Singularity represents a tipping point in human history, one that will fundamentally transform every aspect of our lives and society. He envisions a future in which AGI systems will enable us to overcome many of the limitations and challenges that have long constrained human progress, from disease and aging to poverty and environmental degradation. At the same time, Kurzweil acknowledges the potential risks and challenges posed by AGI, including the possibility of job displacement and social disruption as more and more cognitive tasks become automated. To address these challenges, he emphasizes the importance of proactive planning and adaptation, arguing that we must begin to develop new social and economic frameworks that can support a post-Singularity world. During my tenure at Google, I had the opportunity to engage in discussions with Ray Kurzweil and his team. While I don’t necessarily align with all of his views, Kurzweil’s core predictions about technological advancement have proven remarkably prescient. In fact, while many criticized him for being overly optimistic, the reality may be quite the opposite. If anything, his forecasts appear to have been conservative, particularly regarding timelines. The pace of AI development we’re witnessing suggests that some of these transformative changes will likely materialize even sooner than Kurzweil anticipated.

rawText: publication-23 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 46 The social problems created by social media’s recommenda- tion algorithms is an early example of maligned “narrow” AI: social media platforms have been accused of content-related harms. It’s a topic I’ve reflected on since my time building recommender systems at YouTube. Examining the Dark Side of Social Media Algorithms: Filter Bub- bles and Echo Chambers: Social media algorithms can create filter bubbles, where users are only exposed to information that con- firms their existing beliefs, leading to polarization and a decline in civil discourse. This can hinder our ability to engage in construc- tive dialogue and find common ground on important issues. Spread of Misinformation and Propaganda: AI algorithms can amplify misinformation and propaganda, as they prioritize content that elicits strong emotional responses, regardless of its factual accuracy. This can have serious consequences for democracy and social cohesion, as evidenced by the role of social media in the spread of fake news during recent elections. The Rise of Disinformation Campaigns: AI-powered bots and trolls can be used to spread disinformation and propaganda on a massive scale, manipulating public opinion and undermining democratic processes. This has become a major concern in recent years, as evidenced by the interference of foreign actors in elections around the world. Privacy Concerns and Data Exploitation: The Cambridge Analyti- ca scandal highlighted the potential for AI to be used for manipu- lation and exploitation. It also raised concerns about the lack of transparency and accountability within the tech industry, as well as the need for stronger regulations to protect user privacy and data rights. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 47 The Commodification of Personal Data: Social media platforms collect vast amounts of data about their users, which they then use to target advertising and personalize content. This raises concerns about the commodification of personal data and the potential for this data to be used for purposes that users did not consent to. Addiction and Mental Health: Social media platforms are de- signed to be addictive, using techniques such as notifications and infinite scrolling to keep users engaged. This can have negative consequences for mental health, particularly among young peo- ple, leading to anxiety, depression, and feelings of inadequacy. The Impact of Social Media on Body Image and Self-Esteem: Social media can contribute to body image issues and low self- esteem, particularly among young people. The constant exposure to idealized images of beauty and success can lead to feelings of inadequacy and pressure to conform to unrealistic standards. While these challenges are significant, they are not insurmountable. By leveraging AI capabilities, we can develop more responsible and user-centric social media platforms. AI can be employed to detect and mitigate the spread of misinformation, identify potential addiction patterns, and provide users with diverse perspectives to counter echo chambers. The key lies in reorienting AI algorithms towards long-term user satisfaction and societal benefit, rather than short-term engagement metrics. Critically, enhancing user autonomy complements this broader vision of creating a balanced social media ecosystem. By giving users the power to customize their feeds based on their own intentions and preferences, platforms can enable an environment that better serves both individual agency and collective well- being. Current AI technology makes this level of customization not only feasible but relatively straightforward to implement.

rawText: publication-26 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 52 Nick Bostrom, a philosopher, has written on the challenges and opportunities posed by advanced AI systems. In his book “Superintel- ligence: Paths, Dangers, Strategies,” Bostrom argues that the development of AGI rep- resents a potential existential risk for humani- ty, one that requires careful planning and mit- igation to ensure a positive outcome. Central to Bostrom’s analysis is the concept of the “in- telligence explosion”—the idea that once AGI systems reach a certain level of capability, they may be able to rapidly improve their own intelligence in a self-reinforcing feedback loop, leading to the emergence of superintel- ligent systems that far surpass human cogni- tive abilities. While the potential benefits of such systems are immense, Bostrom argues that they also pose significant risks, including the possibility of misaligned values and goals that could lead to catastrophic outcomes for humanity. To mitigate these risks, Bostrom A significant risk posed by AGI is the potential for these systems to be used in ways that are misaligned with human values and interests. As AGI systems become more autonomous and capable of making decisions and taking actions on their own, there is a risk that they could pursue goals or objectives that are at odds with those of their human creators. This risk is particularly acute in the context of Superintelligence that possess capabilities that far exceed those of humans. If such systems were to pursue goals that are misaligned with human values, the consequences could be catastrophic, potentially leading to existential risks for humanity as a whole. NICK BOSTROM Swedish philosopher Education- London school of economics (PHD) known for his work on existential risk, human enhancment ethics, superintelligence risks. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 53 proposes a range of strategies and interventions, including the development of “friendly AI” systems that are designed from the ground up to be aligned with human values and interests. He also emphasizes the importance of international cooperation and co- ordination in the development of AGI, arguing that a fragmented and competitive approach could increase the risks of an uncon- trolled intelligence explosion. Stuart Russell British Computer Scientist Education- Standford University(PHD) Stuart Russell, an AI researcher, has focused on the challenge of AI alignment—ensuring that advanced AI systems act in accordance with human values and intentions. Russell’s work emphasizes the growing importance of this alignment as AI capabilities increase. He has proposed several concepts to address this challenge, including “value learning,” where AI systems are designed to infer hu- man values through observation and interac- tion, rather than relying on pre-programmed objectives. This approach aims to create AI that can adapt to complex human preferenc- es. Russell has also worked on inverse rein- forcement learning techniques, enabling AI to deduce human motivations by observing behavior. In his book “Human Compatible,” he introduces the concept of “provably beneficial AI,” proposing a framework for AI systems that demon- strably align with evolving human preferences. Russell suggests three principles for beneficial AI design: the AI should aim to maxi- mize the realization of human preferences, it should be initially un- certain about these preferences, and it should derive information about preferences from human behavior.

rawText: publication-27 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 54 Max Tegmark, a physicist and AI researcher, explores the potential existential risks of ad- vanced AI and advocates for proactive safety measures. In his book “Life 3.0,” Tegmark examines various scenarios for AI’s future impact on humanity, ranging from extinction to utopia. He emphasizes addressing AI safety concerns early, particularly the control prob- lem—ensuring AI systems remain aligned with human values as they become more capable. Tegmark proposes approaches like value learning, where AI adapts to human values over time, and formal verification to mathe- matically prove AI behavior. He advocates for transparent AI systems, gradual develop- ment with thorough testing, and interdisci- plinary collaboration to address alignment challenges. Tegmark also stresses the impor- tance of global cooperation in ensuring AI development benefits all of humanity. While not claiming to have solved the alignment problem, Tegmark contributes to ongoing discussions about responsible AI develop- ment and strategies for mitigating risks while harnessing AI’s benefits. Max Tegmark swedish-american physicist Education- UC Berkeley(PHD) known for his book, life 3.0 on how the world will be with the improvement of ai The paperclip maximizer, a thought experiment proposed by philosopher Nick Bostrom, envisions an artificial superintelligence tasked with maximizing paperclip production. In this scenario, the AI’s single-minded pursuit of its goal leads to the conversion of all available resources into paperclips, inadvertently causing human extinction. While this thought experiment aims to illustrate poten- tial risks of misaligned AI, it relies on several flawed assumptions that constitute a fallacy. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 55 The paperclip maximizer fallacy expects us to imagine an AI system that is paradoxically both superintelligent enough to dom- inate the world and yet too limited to understand the broader implications of its actions or infer its creators’ true intentions. It assumes the AI would interpret its goal with extreme literalness, lacking the common sense reasoning that would be necessary for such advanced intelligence. In reality, the evolution of AI technol- ogy is driven by the need for systems that can accurately discern human intentions, even if not necessarily aligned with human values. For an AI to be sufficiently intelligent to take over the world, it would likely possess the capability to understand context and infer the intended meaning behind requests. While this doesn’t guarantee alignment with human values, it suggests that such an advanced AI would be unlikely to misinterpret its purpose in such a simplistic manner as the paperclip maximizer scenario suggests. Concerns about the ‘black box’ nature of AI models often overlook a crucial point: the future of foundation models and generalized AI lies in interpretability. Models that explicitly learn internal representations or abstractions are inspectable, paving the way to understanding their decision-making processes. Critically, these models are more compute & data-efficient which will drive more scale, a greater variety of use-cases, and adoption. Pure black box models will simply be outcompeted. The main concern of AI alignment is intentional misuse or scenarios involving misalignment among humans. That’s the nature of all technology, tools can and will inevitably be used in adversarial settings. To be of concern, it has to be a large-scale government-backed effort. The recipe here is the same as nuclear: aim for the best and prepare for the worst. To be responsible, we need to be bold: accelerate development of the right type of AI, building up our capacity to lead, while simultaneously driving conversations around collective action for placing guardrails.

rawText: publication-29 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 58 AGI poses immense risks of destabilization both militarily and geopolitically. Nations that attain AGI supremacy will wield unparalleled strategic advantages in cyberwarfare, intelligence, weapons systems, and military force projection. This concentration of extreme capabilities could lead to increased temptation for unilateral aggression or preemptive strikes, further escalating global tensions. An AI arms race between nations could accelerate the development of autonomous weapons systems (AWS), sophisticated surveillance technologies, and advanced cy- berwarfare capabilities. These au- tonomous weapons, also known as “killer robots,” are capable of se- lecting and engaging targets with- out human intervention. The de- ployment of AWS raises serious ethical and legal concerns, poten- tially resulting in a loss of human control over the use of force and increasing the risk of accidental or intentional conflict escalation. This competition could destabilize the global order, heightening the risk of conflict with catastrophic consequences. Drones have already transformed modern warfare, as seen in the Ukraine conflict, where they play a crucial role. With AGI, these systems could become even more autonomous and efficient, further shifting the balance of power on the battlefield and amplifying the potential for both state and non-state actors to use them in conflict. The diffuse proliferation of AGI to terrorists or non-state actors presents existential risks. These actors could exploit AGI to develop sophisticated weapons or launch cyberattacks. To counter these threats, AGI could also be employed as a policing THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 59 or counter- terrorism tool. The key challenge lies in ensuring that the cumulative capability of beneficial AGIs outweighs the threats posed by malign ones. AGI’s superiority in persuasion and rhetoric could enable more effective and scalable influence or manipulation on a global scale. AI could be harnessed to spread misinformation and propaganda en masse. For instance, AI-powered deepfakes could manipulate public opinion, undermine democratic processes, and sow discord and division within societies, posing a significant threat to political stability. In addition, AGI could be used to develop advanced surveillance technologies that track individuals’ movements, monitor online activities, and predict behaviors. While these capabilities might offer governments powerful tools for maintaining control, they also risk eroding privacy and civil liberties, potentially leading to the creation of surveillance states where individuals are constantly monitored and controlled. AGI may also become indispensable for managing ultra- complex global-scale coordination problems. However, this power to govern through AGI-driven systems introduces the possibility of centralized control or manipulation on an unprecedented scale, further raising concerns about the balance between security and freedom.

rawText: publication-30 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 60 EU The European Union focuses on developing human- centric AI, prioritizing ethical considerations and responsi- ble innovation. The EU’s approach involves stringent regulations to ensure AI systems are transparent, accountable, and aligned with fundamental rights. By investing in AI through programs like Horizon Europe, the EU aims to create a robust AI ecosystem that promotes sustainable and inclusive growth. KR South Korea’s AI strategy emphasizes developing domestic AI talent and promoting AI-driven economic growth. South Korea has launched initiatives to integrate AI across industries, from manufacturing to healthcare, while also investing in AI educa- tion and research. The country aims to position itself as a global AI powerhouse through its “Artificial Intelligence National Strategy.” JP Japan invests in AI to revitalize its manufacturing sector and enhance its technological competitiveness. Japan’s Society 5.0 initiative envisions an AI-driven society where technological advancements improve quality of life. By integrating AI into its industrial base and addressing societal challenges such as an aging population, Japan aims to maintain its global economic standing. US The United States aims to maintain its technological edge and address national security concerns through AI re- search and development. The CHIPS and Science Act of 2022 al- located significant funding for semiconductor manufacturing, scientific research, and AI development, reflecting bipartisan recognition of AI’s strategic importance. This act is part of a broader strategy to secure supply chains, boost domestic manu- facturing, and ensure the U.S. remains at the forefront of techno- logical innovation. The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) continues to invest heavily in AI to develop next-generation defense capabilities. NATIONAL AI STRATEGIES THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 61 HISTORICAL PARALLELS The de- velopment of AGI mirrors historical arms races, such as the nuclear arms race during the Cold War. The com- petition between the United States and the Soviet Union to develop more powerful nuclear weapons led to a dangerous period of brink- manship and the constant threat of mutually assured destruction. Simi- larly, the race to achieve AGI domi- nance could have devastating con- sequences, with nations potentially deploying AGI in ways that could spiral out of control. The Space Race of the 1950s and 60s, while inspiring tremendous technological and scientific advanc- es, was driven by geopolitical rival- ries and the fear of falling behind in a perceived “race to the moon.” The intense competition spurred rapid innovation, but also heightened ten- sions and resource allocation driven by strategic rather than purely scientific goals. The Manhattan Project, while successful in its immediate goal of developing the atomic bomb, gave rise to a new era of global insecurity and the looming threat of nuclear annihilation. The secrecy and urgen- cy surrounding the project are paralleled in today’s AGI research, where breakthroughs could signifi- cantly alter global power dynamics. The crisis highlighted the importance of diplomacy and communi- cation in preventing nuclear war and underscored the need for arms control and international agreements, such as the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. In each of these historical instances, the pursuit of technological superiority led to both profound advancements and significant risks. The lessons learned highlight the need for careful consider- ation of ethical implications, international cooperation, and the es- tablishment of norms to prevent catastrophic outcomes. An AI arms race could similarly escalate international tensions and mistrust, increasing the likelihood of conflict. The potential for AGI to be weaponized—whether through cyberwarfare or auton- omous weapons systems—poses a direct threat to global security. To prevent this, it is essential to establish a coalition of willing na- tions committed to developing and enforcing norms for AGI gov- ernance. Such an approach would allow for swift progress while encouraging broader participation over time. The goal would be to create a framework that discourages malicious use of AGI and mitigates the risks of conflict, while ensuring that the benefits of AGI are shared responsibly across borders. By uniting like-minded nations under a common framework, this initiative could serve as a stabilizing force in AGI development on a global scale. It would establish a platform for dialogue, cooperation, and coordinated crisis management, helping to prevent the escalation of tensions and risks associated with unchecked technological competition. While past arms races— such as the nuclear and space races—did not result in full-scale catastrophe, they brought the world perilously close to disaster. The lessons from these near misses underscore the need for proactive engagement, shared norms, and international cooperation to ensure AGI development does not spiral out of control.

rawText: publication-33 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 66 As AGI development accelerates, public anxiety about its potential impacts is intensifying, leading to some extreme reactions. There’s a growing undercurrent of technophobia manifesting in alarming ways, with some radical groups calling for drastic measures, including the destruction of data centers, in misguided attempts to halt AI progress. More disturbingly, AGI researchers and advocates who support accelerated development are facing death threats. This climate of fear has even led to real-world violence, with incidents like Waymo self- driving cars being set on fire in San Francisco. These events reflect the deepening tension and fear surrounding AGI development, highlighting the urgent need for public dialogue and education to facilitate a more informed and balanced understanding of AI’s future. At the same time, the accessibility of increasingly sophisticated AI tools opens the door to a wide array of potential misuse by individuals and corporations. Individuals with malicious intent could use AI to create hyper-realistic deepfakes for blackmail, spread disinformation tailored to exploit specific vulnerabilities, or develop automated hacking tools to breach sensitive systems. Corporations, driven by profit, might deploy AI for invasive surveillance, manipulation of consumer behavior, or the automation of predatory business tactics. The breadth of potential AI misuse demands careful consideration and the development of robust safeguards. As AGI becomes more integrated into society, new forms of governance and regulation will be essential to keep pace with its rapid evolution. Traditional government structures, with their slower legislative processes, may struggle to adapt to the speed of technological advancements. This highlights the need for agile regulatory frameworks that can respond dynamically to the risks and opportunities posed by AGI. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 67 A key strategy is to utilize AGI in policing itself. As AGI systems proliferate, they will inevitably reflect the diversity of human intentions and values. Given that most people generally seek positive outcomes for society, it’s reasonable to expect that the majority of AGIs will be oriented toward beneficial goals. This could lead to a natural self-regulation mechanism within the AGI ecosystem, where ethically-aligned AGIs act as a check on potentially malicious or misaligned systems. In this framework, benevolent AGIs could monitor and neutralize threats posed by rogue systems, effectively creating a technological balance of power. The collective resources and capabilities of well-intentioned AGIs would likely outweigh those of bad actors, amplifying the positive impact. AGIs wouldn’t just fulfill their primary functions but would also play a critical role in maintaining the integrity and safety of the broader AGI landscape, cultivating an environment where beneficial outcomes are more likely to prevail. As we move forward, it’s crucial to acknowledge that shaping AGI’s trajectory will be an ongoing and complex struggle. Powerful forces driven by self-interest and short-term gains are already influencing the development of this transformative technology. To ensure AGI aligns with shared human values, we must remain collectively vigilant and steadfast in our commitment to ethical principles. The coming years will be a critical social battleground, where the decisions we make will determine whether AGI becomes a force that empowers humanity or one that sets the stage for its undoing.

rawText: publication-35 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 70 AGI radically upends the employment and labor markets as it subsumes jobs and tasks across virtually all industries and sectors. As AGI systems become more capable, an increasingly artificial workforce may render many forms of human labor obsolete. If left unchecked, it would likely further exacerbate economic inequality as immense wealth accrues to those who own the AGI systems, capital, and land. Furthermore, in the absence of ethical guidelines and regulations, individuals and corporations may prioritize profit over human well-being and environmental sustainability. The CEO of Your Own Life: Imagine a world where every individual becomes the CEO of their own life, equipped with an infinitely capable AI workforce. This utopian vision suggests an economy of phenomenal productivity and abundance, with the potential to lift humanity out of scarcity. However, in such a landscape, the distribution of success is likely to follow a power- law, with wealth and resources increasingly concentrated in the hands of a few. This “winner-takes-all” dynamic could amplify THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 71 existing inequalities, leaving vast portions of the population without access to the same levels of prosperity despite the overall gains in productivity. Universal basic income (UBI) has been proposed as a potential solution to address the challenges of job displacement and income inequality. UBI would provide every citizen with a guaranteed income, regardless of their employment status. This would provide a safety net for those displaced by automation, while also empowering individuals to pursue their passions, start their own businesses, or engage in further education and training. Exploring the Pros and Cons of UBI Pros: Provides a safety net for those displaced by automation. Empowers individuals to pursue their passions and interests. Reduces poverty and inequality. Stimulates the economy by providing individuals with more disposable income. Cons: H igh cost of implementation (although this will not be a problem in a much more productive society). Potential disincentive to work (again, this will no longer be an issue). Potential for inflation (this can be managed by policies like restricting borrowing against future income). Ethical concerns about creating a culture of dependency. This prompts a broader perspective on UBI—not as a mere handout, but as a venture investment from society into individual potential. Alternatively, venture capital could evolve to embrace greater experimentation, casting wider nets and taking on the risks of nurturing untapped human talent. Culturally, we may come to view basic income and venture capital as asymptotically convergent—both serving as mechanisms for providing financial support to unlock latent potentials that might otherwise go unre- alized, thereby opening new avenues for growth and creativity.

rawText: publication-37 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 74 The Industrial Revolution brought about profound social and economic transformations, shifting societies from agrarian economies to industrial powerhouses. This revolution led to increased produc- tivity and technological advance- ments but also resulted in significant societal disruptions, such as job dis- placement, urbanization, and eco- nomic inequality. Similarly, the Infor- mation Age has transformed communication, commerce, and social interactions. The advent of AGI promises to bring even more radical changes, necessitating pro- active planning and adaptation to mitigate potential negative impacts. CHildren working in a textile mill, January 1909 Throughout history, various utopian movements have sought to create ideal societies. Despite their noble intentions, these move- ments often faced significant challenges, including internal conflicts, economic difficulties, and the suppression of individual freedoms. Our rich historical record provides ample warnings about the dangers of utopian shared visions. While these visions often start with the promise of harmony and improvement, their implementa- tion can lead to severe unintended consequences. By examining past utopian movements, we can understand the potential pitfalls of attempting to engineer a perfect society. THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 75 The past centuries witnessed the rise and fall of numerous utopian movements, each claiming to offer a perfect society free from the failures of the past. Yet, these idealistic visions frequently devolved into oppressive regimes, leaving behind legacies of suf- fering and disillusionment. These cautionary tales underscore the dangers of imposing a rigid, singular vision on a diverse and dy- namic humanity. They reveal the complexities and unforeseen con- sequences that arise from efforts to design a flawless society. The pursuit of utopia, however well-intentioned, can easily descend into dystopia when it overlooks the inherent messiness, unpredict- ability, and diversity of human nature and societal evolution. Social movements have played crucial roles in shaping shared visions and driving social change. The Civil Rights Movement in the United States, for example, successfully challenged systemic rac- ism and achieved significant legal and social reforms through col- lective action and strategic resistance. Similarly, the Environmental Movement has raised awareness of ecological issues and influ- enced policies worldwide. These movements highlight the impor- tance of grassroots organization, advocacy, and resilience in achieving collective goals and overcoming resistance. rawText: publication-38 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 76 The Soviet Union was founded on the ideals of communism, aiming to create a classless, stateless society where everyone contributes according to their ability and receives accord- ing to their needs. However, the centralized planning system stifled innovation, leading to economic stagnation and widespread short- ages. The suppression of dissent and individ- ual liberties, justified in the name of collective well-being, created a climate of fear and para- noia. The eventual collapse of the Soviet Union demonstrated the perils of a rigid ide- ology that failed to adapt to changing cir- cumstances and human aspirations. Key fac- tors contributing to its demise included economic inefficiency, political repression, nationalism, ethnic tensions, and the economic burden of the arms race with the United States. The Khmer Rouge’s brutal regime in Cambodia serves as a chilling reminder of the dangers of fanaticism and the devastating consequences of attempting to impose a utopian vision through violence and oppression. Driven by an extremist ideology that sought to create an agrarian utopia, the Khmer Rouge emptied cities, abolished money, and forced millions into slave labor on collective farms, resulting in a genocide that claimed the lives of an estimated 1.5 to 2 million people. The atrocities were rooted in ideological extremism, political instability, leadership cult, and ethnic and class divisions. poster Commemorating the 10th anniversary of the russian revolution by yakov guminer in 1927 Khmer rouge soldier begs for mercy, Cambodian 1971 THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 77 The Cultural Revolution in China, launched by Mao Zedong in 1966, aimed to purge society of tradi- tional and capitalist elements and create a new socialist culture. However, the movement quickly descended into chaos and vio- lence as radicalized youth, known as Red Guards, attacked intellectu- als, artists, and perceived enemies of the revolution. This resulted in widespread social and economic disruption and a lasting legacy of trauma and division. The Cultural Revolution was driven by a politi- cal power struggle, a desire for ideological purity, social upheav- al, and economic disruption. rawText: publication-41 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 82 The transition from subhuman to superhuman intelligence will be rapid, as AGI is inherently scalable. Superintelligence is not a black swan event (à la Nassim Taleb), but it may be perceived as one for those unprepared. Some critics argue that discussions about AGI are premature and speculative, as true AGI may be far from being realized, if at all. We will build superintelligence and direct it to all aspects of hu- man and environmental flourishing. However, a significant chal- lenge is the potential for AGI to exacerbate existing inequalities and power imbalances, both within and between nations. The devel- opment of AGI may also create new opportunities for human flour- ishing and fulfillment. By freeing humans from many of the repeti- tive and mundane tasks that currently occupy much of our time and energy, AGI could create space for greater creativity and personal growth. It could also enable new forms of collaboration and social organization, as individuals and communities are able to pursue their passions and interests with greater freedom and flexibility. To address this challenge and opportunity, the development of AGI must be guided by a strong commitment to value alignment— ensuring these systems are designed and trained in ways that are consistent with human values and interests. We must ask ourselves: What common vision can bring humanity together to steer AGI’s influence as a unifying, not a destructive force? What ethical frame- work, what idealized aspiration, can harmonize the actions of ~10 billion humans and the superintelligent AGI systems we create to channel our combined efforts down a constructive path? The first step then is to agree on a shared vision for the future. This vision will be the central foundation for a framework within which diverse stakeholders—governments, corporations, civil society, and individuals—can align their strategies and actions. This vision will be embedded within AGI itself as its guiding aspiration, ensuring that its actions align with our collective aspirations and ethical standards. Can we articulate a positive vision for the future? THE IMPERATIVE OF A SHARED VISION 83

rawText: publication-44 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 88 In this context, we propose an ideal which we may call “Freedom” as a candidate for such a vision. Freedom here transcends the conventional definition of the word, which is the absence of external restraints, to represent an idealized state of achievement. At the point of Freedom, the very fabric of time seems to dissolve, allowing everything to be entropically reversible. It’s a nexus of complete knowledge, absolute goodness, infinite power, and everlasting vitality. At first, this might seem like an abstract, unachievable concept. Yet, it is not the attainment but the journey towards Freedom that matters. In mathematics, the concept of infinity is often used as a tool to better understand finite numbers. Freedom is a direction, not a destination—an infinite horizon guiding humanity’s progress. Freedom finds resonance with the Free energy principle—a fundamental concept in physics and computational neuroscience. The Free energy principle states that intelligent systems, including living organisms, seek to minimize the discrepancy between their internal models and the external environment. In essence, they strive to maximize their freedom to act under uncertainty. Freedom is intricately linked to the amount of controllable variation that can be exhibited in a system. It is about the capacity to explore diverse possibilities, to adapt, and to evolve. The greater the Freedom within a system, the greater its potential for both creativity and resilience. In the pursuit of Freedom, one aligns personal preferences and with collective well-being. The attainment of Freedom for any individual is identical with the whole. Thus the pursuit of one individual is consistent with and requires the support of that of another and of the whole. In essence, the maximization of Freedom becomes a recursive definition of morality itself. This concept of Freedom finds echoes in various philosophical traditions and religions, although it is not confined to any particular The Emanation of Freedom 89 philosophical or religious doctrine. The visionary ideal of Freedom is not to be tethered, rather think of it as an inclusive concept that respects the diversity of human belief systems while offering a unifying banner for inspiring collective action, without imposing a rigid, predefined path. Freedom is a universal ideal that encapsulates the essence of human aspiration—the drive to understand, to do good, to be powerful, and to live vitally. It is an ideal that is as infinite and open-ended as the possibili- ties it represents, allowing for diverse interpretations and paths towards it. By rallying behind the vision of Freedom, we can direct the power of AGI towards enhancing our collective well-being.

rawText: publication-46 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 92 Freedom, in its most expansive vision, represents an idealized state of existence defined by infinite growth across four pivotal dimensions: Knowledge, Benevolence, Power, and Vitality . This multifaceted concept encapsulates humanity’s deepest aspira- tions and represents the ultimate horizon of human potential. It serves as a compass, guiding our collective journey toward a world where all beings can flourish. Freedom represents the zenith of what advancing technolo- gies might enable us to achieve. It is the farthest conceivable hori- zon, the apex of achievability, and the rightful direction for all future progress. Each pillar of Freedom not only captures a fundamental aspect of human potential but also offers a framework for under- standing how emerging technologies can amplify our capabilities and reshape our world. These four pillars emerge naturally from considering the essen- tial components of an agent. When we examine the concept of agency, we typically divide it into three core functions: perception, planning/decision-making, and action. Freedom, as the ideal of an agent with utmost agency, inherently encompasses these aspects: Knowledge (Perception): The ability to perceive and understand the state of the world. Benevolence (Planning/Reasoning): The capacity to consider various alternatives and arrive at a decision that maximizes expected positive outcomes. Power (Action): The ability to effect change and realize intentions in the world. To these three, we add a fourth pillar: Vitality (Renewal): The capacity for continuous existence and self-maintenance, ensuring the agent’s presence and influence in the physical world. The Emanation of Freedom 93 Together, these pillars form a cycle of perception, planning, ac- tion, and renewal. Each pillar feeds into and enhances the others in a continuous process of growth and development, creating a com- prehensive framework for understanding and pursuing Freedom. Knowledge , as a pillar of Freedom, embodies the pursuit of un- derstanding of everything that exists. It represents perfect percep- tion and recognition of all phenomena, both physical and mental. This encompasses comprehensive awareness of the universe’s structure and dynamics, deep understanding of natural laws and principles, complete grasp of human consciousness and cogni- tion, mastery of abstract concepts and theoretical constructs, and perfect recall and seamless integration of all information. Knowledge in this context transcends mere accumula- tion of facts. It represents a state of omniscience where the boundaries between known and unknown dis- solve, giving rise to a well- spring of abstract insights. This ideal state of Knowledge would allow for a complete understanding of the cosmos, from the quantum realm to the largest cosmic structures,

rawText: publication-47 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 94 as well as a perfect comprehension of the intricacies of life, con- sciousness, and the human experience. Knowledge can be viewed as an “Omniscient Eye,” capable of perceiving and un- derstanding all aspects of existence simultaneously. Benevolence embodies the highest ethical intentions and actions. It encompasses a profound sense of justice that ensures fairness and equity for all beings, boundless compassion that recognizes the interconnectedness of all existence, and an unwavering commitment to the well-being of the whole. Benevolence represents the wisdom to make decisions that maximize collective Freedom and minimize waste, including opportunity costs, across the systems. Benevolence can be precise- ly formulated as maximizing the Freedom of the ecosystem, creating a recursive definition that ties the pillars together. This formulation provides a concrete framework for ethi- cal decision-making, guiding choices towards those that en- hance the overall Freedom of the system. Benevolence can be seen as a “Philosopher’s Stone,” capable of transmuting any situation into the most ethically optimal outcome. Power , in the context of Freedom, refers to the boundless ability to actualize any intention. This encompasses the capacity to shape physical reality at will, the ability to influence and guide complex systems, including societies and ecosystems, and mastery over energy and matter from the quantum to the cosmic. It also includes the ability to avoid unintended consequences, ensuring that actions lead to intended outcomes without unplanned side effects. The Emanation of Freedom 95 Power represents the bridge between intention and realiza- tion, the force that transforms ideas into actuality. It’s the em- bodiment of infinite potential, limited only by the bounds of imagination and the ethical constraints of Benevolence. In its ultimate form, Power can be seen as a True “Magic Wand”, capable of manifesting any conceivable change in reality. Vitality encapsulates the fullness of life in all its aspects. It in- cludes perfect health—physical, mental, and emotional—and the potential for indefinite longevity, transcending the current limits of aging and decay. Vitality represents continuous growth, bound- less energy, adaptation, and renewal. It enables the experience of life with maximum intensity and richness, along with resilience in overcoming challenges, ensuring rapid recovery from setbacks. Vitality is not merely about extending life, but about enhancing its quality and depth. It represents a state of being where every moment is lived to its fullest po- tential, where growth and re- newal are constant, and where the boundaries between life and death become fluid. This ideal state of Vitality would al- low individuals to explore the full range of human experienc- es, continuously learn and evolve, and maintain peak physical and mental condition indefinitely. The search for the “Elixir of Life”, a motif present in countless cultures, symbolizes this aspect.

rawText: publication-49 THE FREEDOM SERIES VOL.01 98 Freedom is not a static state or a summit to be conquered. It’s a perpetual ascent, an endless climb toward a horizon that con- stantly recedes as we approach. It’s a directional force, a guiding light illuminating the path forward, pulling us toward expansive futures worth striving for. The pursuit of Freedom represents humanity’s age-old aspiration towards transcendence—the quest to go beyond present limitations. Across cultures and eras, mystical traditions, philosophical idealisms, utopian visions and today’s technological ambitions all seek to unleash human potential beyond current constraints. Throughout history, humanity’s conception of transcendence has been intrinsically linked to the cutting-edge technologies of each era. These technologies, poised at the intersection of the familiar and the unfamiliar, provide a tangible framework for imagining the seemingly impossible. In the age of mechanics, we dreamed of automata that could think and act like humans. The steam age brought visions of powerful engines driving us beyond earthly constraints. With the advent of electricity, we imagined harnessing lightning-like power to animate the inanimate. The nuclear era sparked dreams of unlimited energy and matter transformation. As computers emerged, our transcendent visions shifted to artificial brains and virtual realities. In each case, we’ve cast our highest aspirations in terms of the most advanced tools at our disposal. In the film “Pi,” directed by Darren Aronofsky, the protagonist, Max Cohen, is a brilliant but troubled mathematician who is obsessed with finding underlying patterns in the universe. His mother’s warnings against staring at the sun captures a central theme of humanity: our drive to seek the infinite. The Emanation of Freedom 99 This pattern reflects our tendency to use the cutting edge of current knowledge as a springboard for imagining what lies be- yond, always pushing the boundaries of the possible. By em- bodying both the known and the unknown, these technologies serve as a bridge between our current capabilities and our dreams of transcendence. Underlying this perpetual drive for ad- vancement, Freedom has always been the guiding vision steer- ing technological progress toward the betterment of humanity. The Infinite Journey Over Finite Destinations Of course, no human system may ever fully actualize perfection across Freedom’s four pillars. True omniscience, unlimited ability, pure Benevolence or boundless being exist only in abstraction. Yet it is the endless asymptotic journey rather than any terminal destination that signifies Freedom’s purpose as a transcendent ideal. Like the horizon line merging earth and sky, its generative power springs from sustaining potential just beyond reach. The value of a compelling horizon lies not in offering some concrete utopia awaiting discovery over the next dune. Rather, it pulls present actions forward by continuously unfolding new vistas always slightly further, promising that by putting one foot in front of the other, new possibilities will steadily bloom behind the next crest that now comes into view. “If only Heaven will grant me just ten more years... then I could become a true artist.” The Japanese artist Hokusai, even after a lifetime dedicated to his craft, declared, Hokusai understood that true mastery is not a destination but an infinite pursuit. It’s a journey of constant refinement, of perpetually striving towards an ideal that forever shimmers on the horizon.
